channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: In Retreat on Ukrainian Fronts, Russia Shows Signs of Disarray
item.description: Confusion and recriminations marked the Russian efforts to call up draftees and claim sovereignty over Ukrainian territory, as well as the Russian response to battlefield setbacks.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Carlotta Gall and Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: A photograph taken during a Ukraine government-arranged tour for journalists showing Ukrainian soldiers in the town of Oskil, in eastern Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Brittney Griner’s Appeal Hearing Set for Oct. 25, Russian Court Says
item.description: The United States has sought the release of the W.N.B.A. star, who pleaded guilty to drug possession and was sentenced to nine years.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:credit: Maxim Shipenkov/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Brittney Griner, the W.N.B.A. star, at a court hearing outside of Moscow in August.

item.title: Prosecution Makes Opening Arguments in Oath Keepers Sedition Trial
item.description: Defense lawyers said the far-right militia had assembled ahead of the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol to await what they hoped would be a decision by Donald Trump to invoke the Insurrection Act.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer
item.media:credit: Susan Walsh/Associated Press
item.media:description: Stewart Rhodes, the leader of the Oath Keepers militia, is facing a charge of seditious conspiracy.

item.title: They Legitimized the Myth of a Stolen Election — and Reaped the Rewards
item.description: On the day the Capitol was attacked, 139 Republicans in the House voted to dispute the Electoral College count. This is how they got there.
item.dc:creator: Steve Eder, David D. Kirkpatrick and Mike McIntire
item.media:credit: Stefani Reynolds/Bloomberg
item.media:description: An aide inspected the official tally to certify the vote hours after rioters had stormed Congress to disrupt the transfer of power.

item.title: Democrats’ Troubles in Nevada Are a Microcosm of Nationwide Headwinds
item.description: Inflation and a rocky economy are bolstering Republicans in their races against incumbent Democrats, motivating “an electorate that simply wants change,” as one G.O.P. consultant says.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina and Jonathan Weisman
item.media:credit: Bridget Bennett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Primary voters in June in Las Vegas. This November, Democrats are facing potential losses up and down the Nevada ballot.

item.title: Ahead of Midterms, Democrats Bet on Abortion Rights
item.description: Vulnerable Democrats in competitive districts have leaned into preserving abortion rights as a closing argument for their campaigns, buoyed by internal polls that show it has moved voters their way.
item.dc:creator: Catie Edmondson
item.media:credit: Aaron Nesheim for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Angie Craig, Democrat of Minnesota, is hoping to appeal to voters with a message about protecting abortion rights.

item.title: Report Details ‘Systemic’ Abuse of Players in Women’s Soccer
item.description: A yearlong investigation found U.S. Soccer executives, N.W.S.L. owners and coaches at all levels of American soccer had turned a blind eye toward years of reports of abuse from players.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Draper
item.category: United States Women's National Soccer Team
item.media:credit: Soobum Im/USA Today Sports, via Reuters
item.media:description: The Portland Thorns and Houston Dash paused their match last October to honor sexual abuse survivors and protest the league’s handling of complaints.

item.title: At NYU, Students Were Failing Organic Chemistry. Whose Fault Was It?
item.description: Maitland Jones Jr., a respected professor, defended his standards. But students started a petition, and the university dismissed him.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Saul
item.media:credit: Janice Chung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students said Maitland Jones’s course was too hard and blamed him and his teaching methods for their poor showings.

item.title: Strange Scenes of Ian: From a Doorbell Camera
item.description: Many people saw glimpses of the storm’s impact on their homes through their phones.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Halleck and Audra D. S. Burch

item.title: Three Ways to Build Back Smarter After Hurricane Ian
item.description: Big storms more becoming more common. That makes it crucial to take climate change into account when rebuilding.
item.dc:creator: Elena Shao
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destruction from Hurricane Ian in Fort Myers Beach, Fla.

item.title: Biden Will Visit Puerto Rico to Survey Hurricane Damage
item.description: President Biden has promised $60 million in storm aid, but Deanne Criswell, the administrator of FEMA, estimated that damages from Hurricane Fiona would cost “in the billions.”
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden visited Puerto Rico nearly two weeks after Hurricane Fiona made landfall.

item.title: U.S. Said to Plan New Limits on China’s A.I. and Supercomputing Firms
item.description: The new rules could be the most sweeping action taken yet by the Biden administration to thwart China’s access to American technology that powers data centers and supercomputers.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur, Ana Swanson and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Long Wei/Visual China Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: A data center in Hangzhou, China. If enacted, new rules would be the strongest push to date by the United States to hit at China’s flourishing supercomputer and data center market.

item.title: Japan Warns Residents to Take Shelter as North Korea Launches Missile
item.description: The test-firing was the latest in a flurry of launchings by the North. The missile flew over Japan and landed in the Pacific.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Jeon Heon-Kyun/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A North Korea ballistic missile launch, seen on television in Seoul, last Friday.

item.title: Three Huge Supreme Court Cases That Could Change America
item.description: The justices will soon hear major cases on voting rights, affirmative action and partisan gerrymandering. Here’s a preview.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court began its new term on Monday. “There are few signs that the court’s race to the right is slowing,” Adam Liptak reported in The Times.

item.title: Supreme Court Takes Up Challenge to Social Media Platforms’ Shield
item.description: The family of a student killed in terrorist attacks challenged a 1996 law that gives websites immunity for suits based on their users’ posts.
item.dc:creator: Adam Liptak and David McCabe
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Supreme Court will decide whether social media platforms may be sued for some user posts.

item.title: Les Rallizes Dénudés: Unraveling One of Rock’s Deep Mysteries
item.description: The Japanese band that emerged in the late 1960s was known for its rumbling rhythms and ear-shredding feedback — but almost nothing was known about its leader, Takashi Mizutani.
item.dc:creator: Ben Sisario

item.title: New York City Is a Trivia Town
item.description: The team sport, more brain than brawn, is played in bars throughout the city and culminates in the King’s Cup.
item.dc:creator: Brittany Loggins
item.media:credit: Lauren Roche for The New York Times
item.media:description: Team members of “Two by the Trash” discuss their answers during the music category of the King’s Cup Trivia Championship in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

item.title: How Liz Truss Did So Much Damage in So Few Days
item.description: The new government squandered its credibility.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Leon Neal/Getty Images
item.media:description: Kwasi Kwarteng, left, the chancellor of the Exchequer, and Prime Minister Liz Truss.

item.title: Is There Anything That Will Make the ‘Former Guy’ Go Away?
item.description: Pardon politics make for strange bedfellows.
item.dc:creator: Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin/Getty Images
item.media:description: Apparently not.

item.title: America Has a Ginni Thomas Problem
item.description: Clarence and Ginni Thomas are Mr. and Mrs. Mutiny.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer/Getty Images

item.title: Lights Out, America! (Songbirds Are Counting on Us.)
item.description: Up to a billion birds die in window strikes every year. But the best way to make the migration seasons safer overall is also the easiest.
item.dc:creator: Margaret Renkl
item.media:credit: Douglas Gochfeld

item.title: Recessions Can Be Like Hurricanes, and Vice Versa
item.description: The similarities are instructive.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by Yuliya Shavyra via Getty Images

item.title: Two Kids. One Pony. Hundreds of Miles to Montreal’s Expo 67.
item.description: Two brothers from the Boston suburbs set out on an improbable journey to Montreal’s Expo 67 by hoof.
item.media:credit: Eric Stange

item.title: These 2022 Mets Are Already Amazing
item.description: He doesn’t have a sport he regularly watches, and I wanted to remedy that.
item.dc:creator: Kathleen A. O’Brien

item.title: A U.S. ‘Ships Act’ Would Break China’s Control of the Seas
item.description: China’s shipping dominance could bring the U.S. to its knees in a conflict.
item.dc:creator: Michael Roberts
item.media:credit: Yannis Kolesidis/European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: A China Ocean Shipping Company container carrier at a port in Greece.

item.title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lyman is an important gateway to the eastern Donbas region.

item.title: Celeste Ng on Race, Class and Suburbia
item.description: Ng discusses her best-selling 2017 novel, “Little Fires Everywhere,” and Judy Blume discusses her adult novel “In the Unlikely Event,” from 2015.

item.title: Dreaming of Spaghetti and (Meatless) Meatballs
item.description: Ricotta polpette, vegetarian Swedish meatballs and plant-based meatballs.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: David Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Barrett Washburne.

item.title: A Times Climate Event: Can Technology and Art Inspire Change?
item.description: Hear from business leaders like Laurene Powell Jobs and Brad Smith, along with storytellers and food innovators in a livestreamed Times event in San Francisco.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Few Customers Get Refunds for ‘Rampant’ Zelle Fraud, Senator’s Report Says
item.description: Elizabeth Warren’s analysis of fraud and scam complaints on the payment network found that banks at times violate a federal consumer protection law.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley
item.media:credit: Jacquelyn Martin/Associated Press
item.media:description: Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, a Democrat, questioned the leaders of several large banks last month about her requests for information about Zelle fraud.

item.title: Top Republican Pledges to Make House Intelligence Committee Less Partisan
item.description: If Republicans take Congress, Representative Michael R. Turner says, he wants to focus on oversight and national security issues. But he is likely to face pressure from his own party.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes
item.media:credit: Susan Walsh/Associated Press
item.media:description: “We need to do the job that we were intended to do,” Representative Michael R. Turner said of the House Intelligence Committee.

item.title: Brazil Braces for ‘White-Knuckle Race’ Between Bolsonaro and Lula
item.description: President Jair Bolsonaro had once looked doomed in the country’s high-stakes election. But now, in a runoff, the right-wing incumbent has a path to re-election.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas, Flávia Milhorance and André Spigariol
item.media:credit: Maria Magdalena Arrellaga for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters gathering in front of President Jair Bolsonaro’s residence in Rio de Janeiro as votes were counted on Sunday.

item.title: Deadly Soccer Clash in Indonesia Puts Police Tactics in Spotlight
item.description: Experts say officers are almost never held accountable for their actions. And in a huge police budget, millions are spent on tear gas, batons and other devices deployed during protests.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Ulet Ifansasti/Getty Images
item.media:description: Indonesian riot police clashed with protesters in Jakarta after official election results were announced in May 2019.

item.title: How Hard Should Your Workout Be?
item.description: Every strenuous exercise involves some mixture of suffering and pleasure. The key to sticking with it is getting the balance right.
item.dc:creator: Alex Hutchinson
item.media:credit: Sean Dong

item.title: What Types of Exercise Reduce Dementia Risk?
item.description: Several large studies have confirmed that vigorous exercise, walking and even doing household chores can greatly benefit the brain.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Is Pilates as Good as Everyone Says?
item.description: The strength and flexibility workout is having a moment. What can — and can’t — it do for us?
item.dc:creator: Danielle Friedman
item.media:credit: Melissa Schriek for The New York Times

item.title: How to Add a Jump Rope to Your Workout Routine
item.description: A jump rope can increase your agility and speed while giving you a great workout in half the time of a run.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Ryan Young for The New York Times

item.title: Book Review: “Breathless,” by David Quammen
item.description: In “Breathless,” David Quammen explores the predictable lead-up to the global Covid pandemic, and the frantic, belated attempts to stop it.
item.dc:creator: Michael Sims
item.category: Breathless: The Scientific Race to Defeat a Deadly Virus (Book)
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: New Jersey first responder Robert Sabia being decontaminated after answering a call in March, 2020.

item.title: How to Solve Intermediate Crosswords
item.description: Moving up to the Wednesday and Thursday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
